case_name: Vanguards Fire General Insurance Co. v. Commissioner of Income-tax

facts.text: Two appeals by special leave directed against the judgment of the High Court of Judicature at Madras

anchor.surface_text: Sikri, J. These two appeals by special leave are directed against the judgment of the High Court of Judicature at Madras in a reference made to it by the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal under section 66(1) of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922

facts.text: Reference made to High Court by Income-tax Appellate Tribunal under section 66(1) of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922

anchor.surface_text: the judgment of the High Court of Judicature at Madras in a reference made to it by the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal under section 66(1) of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, hereinafter referred to as the Act.

facts.text: Question of law referred: Whether rental income from house property received by assessee for AY 1950-51 and 1951-52 exempt under section 4(3)(xii) notwithstanding section 10(7)

anchor.surface_text: , hereinafter referred to as the Act. The following question of law was referred to the High Court Whether, on the facts and circumstances of the case, the rental income from the house property received by the assessee for the assessment years 1950-51 and 1951-52 is not exempt under section 4(3)(xii) of the Act notwithstanding section 10(7) of the Act ?

facts.text: Appellant Vanguards Fire General Insurance Co. carried on fire and general insurance business

anchor.surface_text: The relevant facts are as follows The appellant, Vanguards Fire General Insurance Co., hereinafter referred to as the assessee, carried on fire and general insurance business.

facts.text: Assessee owned a building of which a part was occupied by the assessee for its own business, the rest let out on rent

anchor.surface_text: It owned a building of which a part was occupied by the assessee for its own business, the rest being let out on rent.

facts.text: During previous year ending December 31, 1949 (assessment year 1950-51), assessee received Rs. 8,230 as rent on the portion let out

anchor.surface_text: During the previous year ending December 31, 1949 (assessment year 1950-51), the assessee received a sum of Rs. 8,230 as rent on the portion let out.

facts.text: In accounting year ending December 31, 1950 (assessment year 1951-52), rent received amounted to Rs. 37,200

anchor.surface_text: In the accounting year ending December 31, 1950 (assessment year 1951-52), the rent received amounted to Rs. 37,200.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer excluded these amounts from assessment in view of section 4(3)(xii)

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer in view of section 4(3)(xii) of the Act excluded these amounts from assessment.

facts.text: Commissioner of Income-tax issued notice to assessee under Section 33B to show cause why ITO orders should not be modified

anchor.surface_text: The Commissioner of Income-tax issued a notice to the assessee under Section 33B of the Act to show cause why the orders of the Income-tax Officer should not be modified so as to set right the error committed by the Income-tax Officer in excluding these sums from assessment.

facts.text: Commissioner held that only income chargeable under head income from property entitled to exemption, not income under Schedule for insurance companies

anchor.surface_text: After hearing the assessee, he held that it is only income which is chargeable under the head income from property which is entitled to the exemption laid down in this clause and not income chargeable under the Schedule in the case of insurance companies.

facts.text: Assessee appealed to Income-tax Appellate Tribunal which upheld the order of the Commissioner

anchor.surface_text: The assessee appealed to the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal which upheld the order of the Commissioner of Income-tax.

facts.text: Tribunal stated a case and referred the question to High Court at instance of assessee

anchor.surface_text: At the instance of the assessee, the Appellate Tribunal stated a case and referred the question reproduced already.

facts.text: High Court answered the question in the affirmative and against the assessee

anchor.surface_text: The High Court answered the question in the affirmative and against the assessee.

facts.text: Assessee carried on business of insurance other than life insurance, paragraph 6 of Schedule applies

anchor.surface_text: As the assessee carried on the business of insurance other than life insurance, paragraph 6 of the Schedule applies to it and is in the following terms

facts.text: Supreme Court dismisses the appeals with costs

anchor.surface_text: The appeals fail and are dismissed with costs.

facts.text: Income-tax Appellate Tribunal observed that exemption under section 4(3)(xii) is to income from property and income here is from insurance business

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal observed The exemption under section 4(3)(xii) is to the income received from property and as the income in the instance case is from insurance business, the assessee cannot lay claim to any exemption under this sub-section.

facts.text: Schedule for life insurance mentions income from property (section 9), absence in general insurance significant

anchor.surface_text: Further the Schedule in dealing with life insurance makes some mention of income from property (section 9), while the absence of any such mention in general insurance is significant.

arguments.claim: Assessment of insurance profits completely governed by Schedule rules; no power beyond it

arguments.claim: No power for ITO to adjust insurance accounts beyond Schedule; Insurance Act ensures true profits

anchor.surface_text: In Pandyan Insurance Co. v. Commissioner of Income-tax the court examined the scheme of the Insurance Act and came to the conclusion that the Insurance Act made detailed provisions to ensure the true valuation of assets and the determination of the true balance of profits of an insurance business.

arguments.claim: Life insurance Schedule (para5) deems property income under s.9; general insurance para6 has no such mention

arguments.claim: Insurance revenue account includes actual rents received, not annual value under s.9

anchor.surface_text: The form of revenue account applicable to fire insurance business, marine insurance and miscellaneous insurance business contains the items on the right side Interest, Dividends and Rents, less income-tax thereon. Presumably, the rents here would be actual rents received, and number annual value as determined under section 9.

Impossible to apply s.4(3)(xii) to assessment under s.10(7) read with para6 of Schedule; deletes property head from s.6 for general insurance

holdings.text: The answer to the question must be in the affirmative and against the assessee: the rental income from the house property is not exempt under section 4(3)(xii) notwithstanding section 10(7).

anchor.surface_text: We agree with the High Court that the answer to the question must be in the affirmative and against the assessee.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Special assessment under s.10(7) and Schedule para 6 precludes separate chargeability of rental income under 'income from property' head required for exemption.

holdings.text: It is impossible to apply the provisions of section 4(3)(xii) to an assessment made under section 10(7), read with paragraph 6 of the Schedule.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, it is equally impossible to apply the provisions of section 4 3 xii to an assessment made under section 10 7 , read with paragraph 6 of the Schedule.

holdings.reasoning_summary: By analogy to Privy Council ruling on life insurance proviso, general exemption provision cannot override special Schedule computation lacking property head.

holdings.text: There is no income chargeable under the head 'Income from property' as far as a general insurance business is concerned.

anchor.surface_text: There is numberincome chargeable under the heads Income from property as far as a general insurance business is companycerned.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Absence of property income mention in para 6 (unlike para 5 for life insurance) and composite profit computation under Schedule.

holdings.text: The effect of section 10(7) is to delete the heads 'Interest on securities', 'Income from property' and 'Income from other sources' from section 6 of the Act, as far as general insurance businesses are concerned.

anchor.surface_text: The effect of section 10 7 is to delete the heads Interest on securities, Income from property and Income from other sources from section 6 of the Act, as far as general insurance businesses are companycerned.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Non-obstante clause mandates exclusive Schedule computation, overriding general heads of income for insurance profits.

holdings.text: The assessment of the profits of an insurance business is completely governed by the rules in the Schedule to the Income-tax Act and the Income-tax Officer has no power to do anything not contained in it.

anchor.surface_text: This companyrt had occasion to companysider section 10 7 of the Act and the Schedule in two cases. In Life Insurance Corporation of India v. holdings.reasoning_summary: Precedents (LIC and Pandyan Insurance) confirm exclusive governance by Schedule and Insurance Act provisions for true profits.

holdings.text: The rents in the revenue account for general insurance are actual rents received, and not annual value as determined under section 9.

precedents.case_name: Life Insurance Corporation of India v Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents.cited_proposition: assessment of the profits of an insurance business is completely governed by the rules in the Schedule to the Income-tax Act and the Income-tax Officer has no power to do anything not contained in it; no general right to correct errors in accounts
precedents.cited_holding: the assessment of the profits of an insurance business is completely governed by the rules in the Schedule to the Income-tax Act and the Income-tax Officer has no power to do anything not contained in it there is no general right to correct the errors in the accounts of an insurance business

precedents.citation: Pandyan Insurance Co. v. Commissioner of Income-tax

anchor.surface_text: Pandyan Insurance Co. v. Commissioner of Income-tax the companrt examined the scheme of the Insurance Act and came to the companysusion that the Insurance Act made detailed provisions to ensure the true valuation of assets and the determination of the true balance of profits of an insurance business.

precedents.case_name: Pandyan Insurance Co v Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents.cited_proposition: Insurance Act makes detailed provisions for true valuation of assets and profits of insurance business; rule 3(b) of Schedule does not empower ITO to adjust accounts or correct discrepancies
precedents.cited_holding: the court examined the scheme of the Insurance Act and came to the conclusion that the Insurance Act made detailed provisions to ensure the true valuation of assets and the determination of the true balance of profits of an insurance business. The court further held that rule 3(b) of the Schedule did not empower the Income-tax Officer to adjust the accounts on the basis of a revaluation made by him or to correct the discrepancy between what was entered in the accounts and what was fact

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Western India Life Insurance Co. Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Western India Life Insurance Co. Ltd. The Privy Council held that the third proviso to section 4(1) of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, ... did not apply to an assessment of the profits and gains of a life insurance business under rule 2(b) of the Schedule

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v Western India Life Insurance Co Ltd
precedents.cited_proposition: third proviso to section 4(1) does not apply to assessment of life insurance business profits under the Schedule
precedents.cited_holding: the third proviso to section 4(1) of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, which provided that if in any year the amount of income accruing or arising without British India exceeds the amount brought into British India in that year, there shall not be included in the assessment of the income of that year so much of such excess as does not exceed four thousand five hundred rupees, did not apply to an assessment of the profits and gains of a life insurance business under rule 2(b) of the Schedule to the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922
